title: The New Azir and Xerath Stories: Damn Good.
body:
I was going to post this as a comment in Jaredan's thread, but I didn't want to do a double post before and after reading the stories.

I just read them both, and, seriously, this is an improvement.

Xerath was a slave who served the last emperor as well, and thinks of Azir as nothing more than a spoiled brat.  He wants freedom and the chance to stop what he considers an oppressive system.  His hate has just been boiling, and it's justified.  He's also hinted to have saved Azir or another Shuriman noble's life, for no reward, and mentions Azir having "blood on his hands".  Welcome back motivation for Xerath!

Azir though, really thought he was doing good.  And my favorite line is when he refers to Xerath as "his boundsman, his magus, his friend".  Azir not only trusted Xerath, he thought he was his friend.  That's a connection that hurts to be severed, and we even learn that Azir had a family, a pregnant wife, a son,  and a daughter, who died in the blast.  Now we know why Azir was so stricken by Sivir.  Maybe family resemblance reminds him of the loved ones he lost when Shurima fell.

These are really akin to the old League Judgements in that they tell us why the characters do what they do.  If these stories were released with the Shurima Event, i think the reaction would have been much more positive.  I don't agree that the IOW and Summoners should have gone, but this is a step in the right direction.  Excited to see where the story goes with the serial lores Carnival Knights mentioned.

I know a lot of you are pretty angry with the Lore lately, but you should give these a read.  I really liked them.

I'd be willing to go to bat for the Xerath retcon more than the Trundle one.

Trundle went from a character with an interesting background to "me am strong hit with stick" and got shoved into the Freljord because it felt silly to call the Frostguard a "faction" with one champ.

Xerath went from a character with an interesting background to another interesting background, but one that fits with another champion and ties in more with the world as a hole.
That I can't deny. It's still sad we won't see the old Xerath tho.

And Renekton.

Very interesting how they ended up at this point. Maybe Skarner will play a role in it?

Also i missed this line and it's gut wrenching:

> Where did such hate come from? Azir had never been aware of it.

Azir is just so naiive.  He really had no idea what slavery did to his friend.  He just didn't understand :(

I almost went to tears when I read the part when Azir refer'd to Xerath as a friend and when he mention'd his families death. Not only did the Lore Team make a great story, they just basically said: "SCREW YOU GUYS, YOU WANT A LORE WE GOT YOU A LORE!"

I love these new stories. It's just that it doesn't sound like the old Xerath. Old Xerath was obsessed with raw magic through and through. New Xerath was looking for freedom. It seems to me Riot will just retcon characters and replace them with new ones if it fits their story better. It started with Trundle, now Xerath has joined him as well.** I can't invest in a lore where the writers will just replace characters whenever it suits them**, because in one year, Xerath could be retconned again to be obsessed with political power instead of magic/freedom. It doesn't build any trust with me if characters are just carelessly replaced.

**Edit:** Read an amazing post in a different thread by Valaran Nara (random player). Realised that unlike Trundle, Xerath is almost the exact same character with only a different theme. Instead of a magic theme he now has a slavery theme. He became a tad more evil in addition, but his character is the same aside from that. There is yet hope, now if only Riot would go back to Trundle and make him Trundle again...

The story, *Unbound*, is a key moment in Xerath's life, one that shows him at a certain point in his arc, not who he had been at every point of his life. He was definitely someone who gained great knowledge of Shurima's power. He knew more about the Ascension ritual, what was needed to disrupt it and the power that resulted from it than anyone else at that time. That didn't happen overnight, and it didn't just happen through the course of revenge. 

Xerath's rise was self-made, not just through his involvement with Azir as a child—and how that elevated him from his low position—but also from his own aptitude and ability to gain knowledge that was lost to virtually everyone else. An understanding he sought while under the true and perceived boundaries of his station within Shurima.

Xerath's drive to gain magical power and knowledge are implied within the piece, but *Unbound* is focused on the moment that irrevocably changed Xerath, Azir and Shurima, as well as where the magus was in his mind at that time.
Old Xerath is implied absolutely nowhere. The entire thing is about his desire for freedom and his desire to screw over Azir. And that's not a bad character, but it's not old Xerath.

I'm not saying the Xerath who was known previously is 1-to-1 the same, but his search for knowledge, his impressive ability to figure out aspects of magic, particularly those bound to his society, and the importance to who he was and who he became are part of his journey.

> I'm not saying the Xerath who was known previously is 1-to-1 the same, but his search for knowledge, his impressive ability to figure out aspects of magic, particularly those bound to his society, and the importance to who he was and who he became are part of his journey.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe they are saying that the important part of his character that is missing is his self-sacrifice in the pursuit of understanding magic - along with the key character milestone of sacrificing the final thing holding him back (his love) from completely making the transition to an inhuman magical being. 

An obsessive, relentless and stubborn adoration has been replaced with hatred, spike and vengeance - and I think that's what they are saying is rubbing them the wrong way.

Agreed. We've been presented with an interesting character, but it's not Xerath. This character might be more conducive to some storytelling, but it's not Xerath.

Wait, that sounds familiar... why am I getting deja vu? 
{{champion:43}} {{champion:48}}

The only part of that that I would claim is 'Xerath' is the search for knowledge thing. Even then, old Xerath was all about his path to unlimited magical power, and the steps he would take in order to get there. His judgement and the fridging of his love interest gave him some depth, yeah, but in game, all you would ever see of Xerath is 'I will become free of the chains that bind me and be the master of the arcane!'

It seems that the lore team focused exclusively on A) the 'search for freedom' aspect and B) the 'tragically loses something in exchange for power' aspect. These were parts of Xerath's old character, but I didn't think they were the most important part of his character; it seemed, to me, that everything about Xerath was his desire for magical power. He cares about freedom because the sarcophagus was blocking his path to power, and the fridging was a tragic result of that power, but I still felt his story focused entirely upon that path. 

While there are aspects of old Xerath in the new lore piece, if you told me they were two different characters, I wouldn't think one was particularly similar to the other, especially from the limited amount of lore we have from both of them.

To put it plainly, the endless thirst for power is merely a superficial trait, that is, in fact, shared between new and old Xerath. Why do you think you would say old Xerath does not particularly resemble new Xerath? Because old Xerath merely has a superficial desire and is not humanized- thus, you associate him as purely the desire for power with no associated reasoning as to why he was seeking it. In the end, they both have the same personality, but with new Xerath, you actually know why he wants power.
To me, that's like prefering stale bread to toast. It's still bread- just one has been cooked and the other has been left out to dry for a while.

Old Xerath had a tragedy occur as part of his path to power. New Xerath went on his path of power due to a tragedy. 

How is Xerath's search of power a 'superficial trait' when it's what most of his quotes are about?  He wants power because he wants to become powerful. It's shallow, but it's realistic, and it's not like everyone needs a tragic backstory (though Xerath did have one.)

Why would you want power for no reason? That's not realistic; if you want power, you want to do something with it, be it dominating others, or doing cool magic tricks. If you want power, you want it for something, regardless of how trivial that something is. You don't just threaten the lives of everyone around you for no reason. People can learn how to draw on their own without killing anyone (God only knows how someone did), but why would you just become a beam of energy and disregard the feelings and safety of everyone around you on an impulse? That doesn't make any sense to me at all and sounds more like a gag story.

Superficial trait, in the sense that the pursuit of power is, almost always, a means to an end, as I discussed in the former paragraph. It's something that is interchangable with a myraid of motivations, be it nothing (as before) or revenge and spite (as now). Does it relate to his personality, and thus his quotes? I totally agree. Should they add more quotes and change it up a bit? Definitely.

You're right, not everyone needs a tragic backstory, but every character deserves to be human, at least in a complexity and respect context, and old Xerath was definitely not 'human'.

There is an expression - A Writer writes because not because he can, but because he MUST. It's not a means to and end or anything else. Musicians often talk about making music for themselves and not for any audience. There are people who use rocket cars just to set speed records, and try to surpass them again. There is a movement called transhumanism - folks seeking to be more than what we are (whether or not it's needed or will succeed is not relevant). Why can't a mage seek knowledge and control of power for simple drive of doing so?

My issue with the change is it makes Xerath a genocidal maniac. You say he wasn't human before, but blowing up his town in an accident (humans are imperfect after all, everyone can relate...) while following his quest for mastery of a subject vs killing everyone in Shurima for reasons that the victims won't even know? Freeing the slaves by unbinding their mortal coils? He knows it will all end in horrific destruction and that's just insanity. I find that far harder to relate to. 

Not to mention this game already HAS a magical lord of evil. He's just tiny.

Yes, actually, tons of people want power because they want to be powerful. He wants to become the master of the arcane because he wants to be incredibly magically powerful. It's not an 'impulse', it was something he decided long ago.

He wants to get the power so he can be powerful. Is that so unbelievable?
That did not address anything I said at all.

I addressed your first two paragraphs. You expressed doubt that 'I want power because I want to be powerful' is a realistic motivation, and I claimed otherwise. How is that not addressing the vast majority of your comment?

Personally, ive been holding back my thoughts on this because ive read somewhere that this isnt the whole story.
at this point ive got nothing left to make me think anything else is coming in the near future. so allow me to say a few thoughts here.

first, this lore was EXTREMELY well written. i enjoyed everything about it, except attaching xerath to it. 
unless something comes out to add back the quest to attain as much magic power as possible / have unlimited magic power.... he's just not the same to me.  that was THE MOST IMPORTANT part of his identity to me. other than knowing xerath disliked azir why would he chose THIS way to screw him over? where is his drive to learn the secrets of magic itself? not to dominate or take revenge like an a-hole, but just to know what the secrets / limits are.

I'm going to continue to wait, but for now.... very disappointed while still impressed with the quality. 
but still disappointed you guys tried all this without being close to ready to present it. and changed my personal favorite part of xerath. but good effort 15% of my trust that you guys know what you are doing has been redeemed.

Im not sure his old motivations where he only sought unlimited magical power will ever return... his ascension has granted him that now but that was a side effect of his true goal which was to steal ascension from azir. His quest for knowledge and power for only himself changed into the means for revenge. I don't think pre ascension xerath sought domination at all. Pretty sure his only goal was to take away what Azir wanted/sought after because what he, xerath, wanted/sought after was unobtainable through his own power, but was within Azirs power.

I am curious though why his self centered desire for unlimited magical power was your favorite part of old xerath?

it was my favorite part because I just really enjoy the idea of unrestricted magic power. i know its not a great answer but its kinda something id like to have myself.
 and xerath had ZERO desire to use that power for anything other than learning the "secrets of magic" 
he screwed over the only person he cared about accidentally while doing so though (they died during his ascension ritual)
which meant he had no desire to stop regardless of the dangers of his ritual, but he harbored no ill will towards anyone.

Hmm... interesting point of view. I would not say that old xerath had zero desire to use his power for anything other than learning though. He wanted to possess untold magical power and be able to see its true source. To say he did no harm to others in his pursuit is a bit naive. There were bound to be secrets and sources that others wouldn't just freely give him, I never saw Xerath as one to take no for an answer though. If he meant no harm in his quest why did the other mages of shurima imprison him once he did ascend. They knew that Xerath held little value in the life of others since one of his goals was immortality. In the eyes of an immortal, a mortal existence is futile since they will inevitably die no matter what, be they young or old.

he never intentionally harmed others. he didnt care if they got hurt, but his goal wasn't "make that guy suffer" 

he got imprisoned because the guy who just essentially magic nuked your country isn't someone whose opinion is not going to be taken as valid and he is going to be seen as a massive threat.

> I am curious though why his self centered desire for unlimited magical power was your favorite part of old xerath?

Because it was part of delivering the idea of his 'Magus Ascendant' story - He was more like Viktor is now (without the pushing his technological revolution...) focused and by virtue of his ability and obsession was able to reach his transcendent form. In fact, giving neo-Xerath a desire to ravage and create a Revolution feels like they just wrote lines for the wrong champion. 

And the generic genocidal maniac theme now...

> I'm not saying the Xerath who was known previously is 1-to-1 the same, but his search for knowledge, his impressive ability to figure out aspects of magic, particularly those bound to his society, and the importance to who he was and who he became are part of his journey.

I'm a believer that "explained" is better than "implied."  My humble suggestion would be to add one paragraph to Xerath's story that shows this obsession with acquiring the knowledge he needed to reach his goal of freedom.  Something like:

"*While the boy played in the halls of his palace, Xerath spent his time seeking an answer to his problem.  While the growing boy learned the ways of being an emperor, Xerath found the answer in the Ascension ritual.  While the young man trained to be a defender of Shurima, Xerath learned everything he could about the ritual, to the point where he knew more about the Ascension than anyone would have thought possible.  While the prince was falling in love and starting a family, Xerath schemed to sabotage the ceremony to finally gain his freedom.*"

It's not perfect, I'll admit.  However, adding something like that would help "new" Xerath mirror the "original" Xerath's obsession with acquiring knowledge for his personal benefit.

>the "original" Xerath's obsession with acquiring knowledge for his personal benefit.

I don´t think he actually wanted to gain personal benefit here, he had been obsessd with the arcane, not with any goals a "normal" human would have given himself...he did seek knowledge above power. 
His reasons had been way beyond the simple revenge-pattern that drive him now.

> >the "original" Xerath's obsession with acquiring knowledge for his personal benefit.
>

> His reasons had been way beyond the simple revenge-pattern that drive him now.

Fair point, but I'm trying to reconcile the old and the new Xeraths.
yea well...that would have been the job of the lore team, unfortunatelly they failed.

You are focusing in to much on this single story. This further detailed why he betrayed Azir but does not go into detail about who xerath is now...

I would remind you of the short blurb at the end of the shurima event that spoke of his goals. His present day existence resonates more with old Xerath. I would also mention that this story gave you a glimpse of what xerath was like right before he underwent ascension and does not speak to his person after that. His ascension was not a normal one. We still don't know ho much his mind was affected during and after his change.

If what you are concerned about is the fact that his new lore does not have him fervently seeking out sources of magic to forcibly ascend into a greater being... I still think this story touches on that. He obviously did not just wake up one morning knowing exactly how to sabotage the ascension ritual. he actively sought to improve his knowledge of magic in order to put his plan in motion. I would say they actually held pretty close to xeraths old personality but rather than putting it right in front of your face word for word, they have portrayed it with much more subtlety and finesse.

edit: after a bit more reading of some others responses i have somewhat repeated them but I do have a bit more to mention. Xerath has changed. While comparing the old and new depiction is interesting and worthwhile, just stating that he is nothing like old xerath is extremely one sided and considerably false. His motivations and his ~~location~~ *Situation* are the only things that have really changed. I actually thought much like you before I read this short story, I thought new xerath didn't resemble old xerath in the slightest... after reading his story however I realized he is still much alike the old xerath.

I would also like to propose a question to you. If I presented you with 2 books to read: one where the protagonist is seeking ways to make himself stronger and more powerful to be better than the rest, and one about a protagonist that seeks out new knowledge and power in order to exact revenge on someone he once considered his friend who did not hold a promise he had made, which would you want to read?

> edit: after a bit more reading of some others responses i have somewhat repeated them but I do have a bit more to mention. Xerath has changed. While comparing the old and new depiction is interesting and worthwhile, just stating that he is nothing like old xerath is extremely one sided and considerably false. His motivations and his location are the only things that have really changed. His motivations changed, as you said and that is a major thing. If you take Riven and take out her motivation, which is to reform Noxus, to substitute it with something else, like honing her sword skills to make Noxus greater, you get a whole different character. Motivations are a core part of the character. Look at Graves, his only major characterization is actually his will to settle things with Twisted Fate. If you changed that, you'd have another character.
Changing the focus from "achievement of true magic and knowledge beyond any limit" to "taking revenge on someone and ascending just to spite him" is no minor step. It's a huge one. I don't say the latter can't be a good story, I'm saying it's not a *Magus Ascendant* story, the focus is on a totally different note. Old Xerath was so fascinated with the arcane to kinda be oblivious of other things, like his own real desires, which he only too late realized were tied to human feelings he would lose pushing his magic further. His tragic loss of what he sought caused by his own mistake, pushed him beyond the no-return point and completed his growth into a Magus Ascendant who completely embraced the arcane and got his humanity consumed by it, reaching a different state of existence which enables him to "see the forces which hold the universe together" and go beyond human comprehension.
It's just a different theme from the new Xerath's one and for the *Magus Ascendant* character of the game the old theme was more befitting and coherent.
Let's put it this way: if you didn't know anything about old Xerath and his kit and quotes in-game, what would you expect him to be about after reading *Unbound*? Would you expect him to brag about him being true magic and unlimited power?

> I would also like to propose a question to you. If I presented you with 2 books to read: one where the protagonist is seeking ways to make himself stronger and more powerful to be better than the rest, and one about a protagonist that seeks out new knowledge and power in order to exact revenge on someone he once considered his friend who did not hold a promise he had made, which would you want to read?

I'd read the one written better and which entertained me the most.
I don't judge books by their back cover.

I can see your point, motivations do make a big difference and with that in mind he isn't the same as he was. I will also agree that the old xerath was more befitting of a magus ascendant but I disagree on it being coherent. I would go as far as to say that it was a jumbled mess.

The way he was laid out before described his life goals and that he ascended to become something more than human. Then it went nowhere. His lore after his ascension was merely to describe why he looked the way he did in game and why he went to the league. We don't even know if he even reached his goal of reaching ultimate awareness once he ascended. we don't even find out if ascending was actually necessary to reach his goal. In fact... the whole ascension part of his story was to make it easier to understand why he looked the way he did in game.

It is not all that surprising why his story was rewritten to how it is now if you look at it that way.

well, noone can read that out of what we have so far - so either release the whole story once in a while, or bear the utter disappointment of quite a lot of people that once loved the Lore of Runeterra.
On all criticism it´s always "you don´t know the whole story" - and that´s exactly the problem, we have just no story anymore, just a few tiny fragments...and a lot of emptiness.

I feel this is a problem with the way Narrative is doing things right now:

There have been a lot of posts from Narrative where they tell us that "this is just a moment in the character's life, don't extrapolate too much from it", all right, that makes perfect sense. But is that going to be the default from now on? Because it makes it very hard for us to grow attached to characters when all we have from them is a collection of moments we can't draw too much from.

People grow attached to characters because of their wholeness, not because of what they did in this or that crucial moment. Crucial moments in particular, while they make for very interesting (if shallow) storytelling, are some of the worst moments to judge a character from. Sure, we can see what they do when under great stress, but that is only one (very tiny) aspect of who they are.

I'm just worried that this new trend of short, dramatic stories is going to end up with unknowable characters.

He was definitely someone who gained great knowledge of Shurima's power. But that piece of story should be the one players enticed by the in-client abstract read to get an idea of the character. From *Unbound*, I'd expect more of a Spartacus (in spirit) than a *Magus Ascendant*. Magic and wizardry are only on the background, Xerath could have been easily a mere secretary in the story and physically shove aside Azir as in the facebook images Riot published, the story would have gone the same.
There's no perception of Xerath as a powerful mage, nor any real stressed magic-related merit in his ascension. He is not the mage who went beyond what all other Shuriman mages did he once was, he is someone who had the time and patience to go dig up ancient knowledge. One doesn't need to be a mage to do so, he could've been a librarian and that would've made just as much sense.
Focusing the whole piece on "freedom" rather than Xerath's drive for the arcane just leaves one wondering why in-game his quotes should all be about power and "the will of man unbound by flesh".
In the piece, which should be the one introducing new players to the characters, Xerath is never presented as someone who wants to ascend because he feels constrained by his mortal condition and is willing to become true unlimited magical power. He is presented as a slave who feels wronged by his master and thus seeks vengeance in the most spiting of ways, opting for a genocide in the process which just makes him inhuman because of the complete lack of any thought towards other fellow slaves who will die because of him.
I can't feel him delivering on the *Magus Ascendant* fantasy, his most prominent traits in this story, which should be the one showcasing him to new players (I like to point this out), are scheming and vengeance, he thus treads into Swain's territory for the first part and into many other's for the latter (Tryndamere, Graves...), without hitting his own niche.

This is only my humble opinion and I would be most delighted to read yours regarding this.

How did Xerath vaporize Azir's family despite being nearly immediately sealed in a tomb?

And saying it was the ascension itself doesn't work, because then the same thing would've happened to Azir's body, so he couldn't have even been revived, ever. Also, the glaring plot-hole of Sivir is still descended from him, but the family died...

...AZIR HAS A SECRET TWIN, MEXICAN SOAP OPERA AZIR CONFIRMED, DIOS MIO~

Azir mentions that he was "frozen in the air and watched" as his family/friends/people were destroyed.  Although the Ascension was imperfect, it quite possibly could have protected him, as he was at the epicenter.  Also keep in mind that the Xerath story stops as Azir is about to perform the ascension, and Azir's only covers what happened right after it failed.  Anything inbetween that is unknown, and likely what occurred in the slides shown on Facebook, with Renekton/Nasus confronting him.

Jaredan mentioned the descent thing as well, but said he wasn't going to spoil it.  So it's at least on Riot's plate.  Azir might have had kids that weren't present at the ritual.

Regarding the time between the Ascension ritual and Xerath's confrontation with Nasus and Renekton: I have one finger on my nose and with my other hand I'm pointing at LordHippoman.
